title: `non_snake_case` warning on generated route parameter

labels.name: deficiency
labels.description: Something doesn't work as well as it could

body:
- Rocket Version: 0.4.1
- Question: `non_snake_case` warning for the rocket generated route parameter, e.g. `__rocket_param__id`.

## Actual Code:

``` rust
// The normal `check` route requiring `AdminUser` to be presented
#[get("/admin/data/check?<id>")]
pub fn check(_user: AdminUser, id: String) -> Result<Template, Redirect> { ... }

// The `check` route where `AdminUser` doesn't exist, simply redirect to "admin/login"
#[get("/admin/data/check?<_id>", rank=2)]
pub fn check_fail(_id: String) -> Redirect { Redirect::to("/admin/login") }
```

And the warning generated by rust:

```
warning: variable `__rocket_param__id` should have a snake case name
  --> src/routes/pages/admin/data/check.rs:34:19
   |
34 | pub fn check_fail(_id: String) -> Redirect {
   |                   ^^^ help: convert the identifier to snake case: `__rocket_param_id`
   |
   = note: #[warn(non_snake_case)] on by default
```

In this example, I'm trying to implement `check_fail` backing up the normal `check` route when there's no `AdminUser` presented. (I think this is almost identical to one of the example usage of `route` so I guess I don't need to elaborate a ton on this.)

Of course I don't need the parameter `id` in my `check_fail` function because I'm just redirecting it to `/admin/login` (as there's no `AdminUser` presented). But I still need the `?<id>` part in the route because otherwise this wouldn't match the original admin route. If I use `id` here then rust compiler will be yelling at me saying that "you are not using this `id` in the function, so you should change it to `_id`". Ok now I change the parameter name to `_id`, and rust is complaining that the rocket generated parameter name `__rocket_param__id` not matching the snake case (because there are two consecutive `_` before `id`.)

Usually this kind of unused variable problem will be fixed just by prepending `_`. But right now even if I add `_` it wouldn't get through the warning. Rocket also does not allow me to use an ignored `_` as the variable name. So what do we usually do in this case?

**Potential Solution**: Add a check on Rocket's side checking whether a parameter starts with an underscore (`_`). If it is then you don't append a trailing `_` at the end of `__rocket_param`. So if my variable is called `_id`, the generated variable name will be `__rocket_param_id` instead of `__rocket_param__id`. Therefore the rust compiler will not complain about the snake case violation.
